The Egyptian Gazette -
FRIDAY, MARCH 31, 1905.
The Customs Administration’s statistics for
the trade of Egypt during the past year have
just been issued. There returns show an enormous
expansion in the volume of trade, which is greater than that of 1903 by more than one and quarter million starling in exports and
nearly font millions sterling in imports. Were we- to consider the figures of the gold coin imported (over £7,600,000) and exported (over £2,730,000) the total increase would be found to be enormous.
Such trade statistics, of course, constitute only one of the indications of the great wave of prosperity that is passing over the country. All other criteria point unmistakably to the same conclusion. Banking and other capital from foreign sources is pouring into Egypt; a new Limited liability company appears almost daily, the price of land, both for agricultural and building purposes, has risen enormously Egyp­tian securities on the local and foreign market stand at quotations which dam the con­fidence of investors in the future develop­ment of the country, and large blocks of them have been taken off the. foreign markets by purchasers in Egypt; the revenues increase notwithstanding continual reductions in taxa­tion ; the population, both native and foreign, is waxing in numbers and in wealth, and the standard of comfort of the former is ruing year by year.
In another column we have dealt with some aspects of Anglo-Egyptian trade, typical y in regard to the shrinkage of our imports into Egypt. Much has beau said about the want of enterprise of the British merchant as com­pared with his foreign competitor*, and we are compelled to admit here in Egypt, where them are ample opportunities of judging, that a great deal of it is well-founded. Wo are aware that there are certain artificial disadvantages against which British find it extremely difficult to contend, even in a neutral market such as this. Dumping, for instance, will account for some of the loss of trade in steel and cotton yam. But dumping will not serve to explain the successful com­petition of our rivals in certain lines oi cotton fabrics and in numerous less important articles of manufacture.
It is especially to these smaller branches of trade that we should like to direct the attention of our countrymen, fur it is there that trade might be built up to compensate for that which has been lost in the staple articles oi British export, cotton and metal goods/- Although a growing market, Egypt is not an easy one to work in, and its difficulties are apt to deter new-comers from commencing operations. We may state in a few words what a march*, intending business with Egypt must be on pared to do. He will probably have to work.
credit terms, have an agent thoroughly) acquainted with the market, with whom him must keep constantly in touch; his good) must be cheap, and adapted to the taste and needs of the consumer. Our enterprising rival* from Continental countries have been working the market assiduously on these lines for many yean. To the success of their
j efforts the trade returns are sufficient tons of
money.

div.head: PEACE IN SIGHT,
MR. ROOSELVELT AS MEDIATOR
div.p: NEGOTIATIONS PROGRESSING
EARLY SUSPENSION OF HOSTILITIES
LONDON, March 31. –

The “Tides’’ learns from St. Petersburg that Russia and Japan have selected President Roosevelt to act as mediator. Negotiations are. already in progress; An early suspension. Of hostilities, may be expected (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, March 29.
It is understood that Russia has made known to Japan the negative conditions under which she is prepared to negotiate, for peace, namely no cession of territory, and no indemnity.
• A -Russian semi-official agency, says the despite the genera inclination in, favor of the conclusion of the war, Russia has not prepared to proposed, peace conditions. (Reuta:)
LONDON, March 30.

Despite semi-official contradictions, there is every- reason to believe that Court Lamsdorff has latimated, in contain' friendly quarters, the- Conditions which Russia is- prepared to entertain. There will probably be
INSURRECTION SPREADING
ST. PETERSBURG March 29.

The insurrection, in Georgia is spreading. It is stated that the-authorities in the mountain districts have been: deposed; and a provisional government proclaimed. - Anarchy reigns in Batutn, Erivan, and Kars. (Reuter: j
ST. PETERSBURG March 30.
The insurrection is increasing in the Caucasus.
THE FINNS AND THE WAR
LONDON, March 27,

The “Daily Chronicle" understands from St. Petersburg that the Finnish Senate has offered to contribute a million sterling towards the expenses oi the War, on condition that no far east. The Tsar, after a long consultation with the Ministers accepted the offer. 26,000 men are, consequently, exempted from service. . . (Reuter.)

• LONDON; March 31.',
The "Daily-Mail” learns from Aden that 16 colliers are leaving Djibouti singly under sealed orders.
They are bouujl for Batavia or Diego.Garcia. (Reuter.,

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL,
div.p: SAVOY SMALL DANCE,—The last small dance, of the season at the Savoy Hotel will be held, tomorrow.
THE "CYPRUS JOURNAL” -for March contains" interesting" article on; “Odium,’' Tree pruning, Soap-making in Cyprus, etc,
THE SPOKEN ARABIC of EGYPT.—A new and revised edition of Judge Wilshire’s monumental work has just, been issued.
RED SEA Lighthouse -- We are asked 'to thank Mrs. Swinglehurst for a gift of books and paper for the use of the Red Sea lightkeepers.
FATAL TRAM- ACCIDENT.— Yesterday Afternoon a native boy was run over and killed by a tram in the Moharrem Bey quarter of Alexandria.- - lx
ALL SAINTS CHURCH—-The Rev. Professor Sayce will preach on Sunday morning next at AJ1 Saints' Church, Cairo! The service begins at 10:30.a.m.
THE BRINDISI MAIL will close at the G. P.D Alexandria, at 3 p.m. on Sunday. A new mail now leaves every Monday via Port Said and Marseilles.

SUEZ CANAL.—9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 28 th inst. 5 of which were British, 1 Dutch, 1 Egyptian, 2 German. The, day’s receipts were frs. 265,088.23 making the total from the last inst 5;628,695.

FATAL ACCIDENT.—The body of another native workman was recovered yesterday from underneath the debris of the foundations of the house which collapsed in Stamboul-street on Tuesday. This brings up the total number victims to four.

. P. & 0.—.Residents in Egypt will Weighted to hear that the Peninsular and Oriental Steam Navigation Company are about to follow the example of other navigation companies in regard to Egypt and to charge a summer rate for residents.

EGYPTIAN INSTITUTE—A meeting of the Egyptian Institute will be held Monday next, 3rd April, at 4 p.m. Dr. Apostolides will lecture on the history of the Alexandrian. Greek and Dr. Bay will deal with the analogies and concordances between, music and art Some elections of new members will; be

FATAL HYDROPHOBIA. —Our Mit Ghamr Gor respondent stales that a mad dog hit three parsons in Sandabast, near Zifta, but it was not until, the brute had bitten a fourth Victim, who succumbed, that the village authorities took any notice, Our correspondent - surges to that the village barber- surgeons (Halaak el Siha) should. be entrusted with the task of attending to such cases, as the Markus authorities do not trouble about the matter.

div.head: CRIME AT ASSIOUT.
div.p: SERIOUS STATE OF THINGS.
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT).
Assiout, March 26.
- I mentioned in my last correspondence that crime
in Assiout was increasing terribly and' that this-
state of things Was mainly due to there being
something wrong with the police. I will give two
cassias proof of this contention.
Four days ago, a telegram was sent from the
Mamour of Abnoub to the Parquet al Assiout
saying that a woman’s body bad been found
floating on the Nile near. Abnoub. Two boors later,
another telegram arrived stating that the. body was
bruised in many places and that the woman must
have been murdered Before her dead body was
thrown into the river. The Mamour added in this
telegram that the Abnoub doctor was absent and
asked- for the Assault doctor to be sent it once.
Accordingly the doctor, accompanied by the
Substitute of the Parquet, went to Abnoub But, on
their arrival they found, to their great astonishment,
that the body bad disappeared and there were no
traces of it.
On being interrogated the Mamour accused he M
OR wen of ordering the ghaffirs to dispose, of the
body in: the Nile, so that they might not have an
additional crime in their market. The Moawen in his
turn accused the Mamour. Enquiry is now being
made, riot shout the mtirder case, lmt rihont the
iesponsibility of the Mamour and Moawen. The
President of the Parquet, the Inspector of the
Ministry, of the Interior and the Moudir attend the
enquiry. Whatever maybe the result of their
investigation; and whether it be proved that the
Mainour, or the Moawen is responsible; the Market,
as a whole, is the cause, of an occurrence which
looks serious enough to come undergo head of
crime. So it is with policemen in the provinces. A
crime. is hushed up that the list at the end of the.
month may appear 'small, and sometimes a
policeman accuses an innocent person because
the real perpetrator is unknown.
The second case 1 am going to mention proves
The murderer was an enemy of the Omdeh and
the other was a friend of the criminal The Court
after two days examination found out that he was
innocent, and accordingly condemned the Omdeh
and his men to six month imprisonment with hard;
labor for bearing false witness. •- :
Such is the management of criminal cases here.
The difficulty lies in the fact the police official from
the ghaffirs at the bottom up to memoirs at the top
are

responsible for finding the author do every crime.
They are liable to a penalty in cases where they
cannot find out a criminal. All natural result of this
organization, a by no means small numbers of
innocent people are committed for trials every day.
The results frequently are firstly the real criminal
escapes punishment and secondly, and secondly
an innocent person is condemned. The guilty man
finding himself victorious, as he has carried out his
criminal intention without being punished for it, is
encouraged to commit more crimes- The second,
in his turn, finding that he was unjustly condemned
because of- false witness given against him by
omdehs and ghaffirs, makes it -his . first object on
leaving prison- to revenge himself) and again-more
crimes are committed.
Although illustrations of m statements occur. every
-day, yet the Ministry of the Interior sticks
obstinately to its legations. I am informed by the
local official here that the Ministry is continually
urged by the inspectors to change this vicious
system but the all to no effect. I have therefore sent
this plain statement of fact "to. the “Gazette" in
order that the supreme authorities may be made
aware of the state of things and change the present

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive spent yesterday on his estates at
Ismailia.
His Highness attended midday prayers today at
the, Mosque of Sultan Al Moayad.
LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
The, General Assembly of the Legislative Council
wilt-meet at 10 a,m .on Monday. H.H., the
Khedive will. inaugurate the session. The
Ministers will he present and the Khedive, utter
the usual opening speech, will submit the decree
relative to the. destruction of the cotton worn to
the assembly.
On Monday next also, the Legislative Council oil -
will discuss the now regulations concerning the
administration of Marsa Matrouh and will note the
receipt of a letter from the Government informed
them that the decree relating to lottery has been
promulgated its new form after being approved by
the-Mixed Courts.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY,
div.p: ATHLETIC NO-fES.
We would. remind out readers. that the. entries
for. the athletic sports promoted by tie Alexandria
Amateur. Athletic Club close on Saturday, April 1,
so intending competitors who are not yet members
should send in their names for election without
delay. We hear, that the entries are likely to be
more numerous than last year, though several of
last. year’s runners will-not be seen. Shilling, the
1902 champion, will not compete, and Matheson,
who put up such a good fight in the pole jump last
year, has left the country. His venerable opponent,
however, is with us still, and though Buffering from
a football injury, is practising.' We hear tho ET.C.
staff have got odt 'some new athletio blood which
we heartily weloome. In the Veteran’s raoe the
favorite has not been discovered, there being'throo
previous winhra amongst- the entrants. Thiq' ought
to be a good race, but we would like to see many
more of the- good-old- have beohs competing!
Surely they •are not afraid of their ages being
calculated' from their starts? The hurdle rape
promises to-be more interesting than at talent
meetings, there being a fair number of good
'entries. It ‘is very regrettable that the Earl
and‘Countess bf Crompr find it impossible to honor
the gathering with their presence.

members will receive their tickets and

p.hi: PROSPECTS OF THE COMPANY- SUBSIDIARIES TO HE FORMED.

div.p: The annual ordinary general mooting of the members of the Nile Valley Block “E," Limit­ed, wo* held in London oN Match 23 under the presidency of Mr. 0. \V. Ramaay (the chairman of the company).

S The Chairman, before proving- the adoption ■ of the report of the directors and the accounts, said 4 few words to »how the protection given to investor in the mining industry of Egypt J Turning to the balance shoot, since the issue (d this report the remaining shares—3,260— had be applied for and issued, thus complet­ing the issue of the entire w of £3.

I hi the HuiigoL concession the' amount expend­ed was for tho exploration of an area of about miles, which comprised a geo­logical survey of ilm area, the locating ol old workings and the sinking of four pits or shafts m.i justify them in boring for coal, which hud been most ably done by Sir. U. U. Carey, who was iu charge. The income and expenditure account was most moderate, and, ho did not think, required comment. With regard to Block ‘T.’." when the rirat expedition was sent to this property they sank eight small shafts with a view to locating the reef, but Jound indications at the northern part of the block the more . favorable, and os the capital at their disposal was limited they concentrated the work upon this particular shaft, the results of which were so clearly shown iu the reports of Mr. Norway, and which had been endorsed by the engineers, Messrs. Lake and Currie. The total footage was 1,083 ft. in drives and sinking. They would ob­serve by the plus accompanying the report that they were now driving both north and £9util at the 100 ft. level j also that as they had previewed in depth the reef which they discovered had been improving in value. It was new established that the reef ou Biock “JS" w.is the same fissure as that existing at the Um Garaitut mine, consequently no doubt Would exist in the minds of engineers or others w to the continuity of the reel and its values. He was continued in this by a clause in Mr. Newbury’s report—an do rood by Messrs. Luke and Currie— in which ho said that the strike, dip and general appearance at the Lode led to the belief that they wero ou the same fissure as the Nile Valloy Company at Um Uaraiort.

They were much encouraged by tho work that had been done, and ware pushing it for­ward with-all the energy possible. By the courtesy of the Hilo Volley Company they had nada arrangements for irial curbing with the mill of three stamps, which would no utilised in ascertaining alues. They bad also marie an application to that company fur the use of their heavy stamps for bulk samples, and he had no doubt this would be arranged. They hud some 1W tons which they could commence to crash. Hu could not, say how hopeful they were in to. the ultimate value of this mine,: which they wore anxious should bo among the. pioneer mines of Egypt. (Applause.) He read , letter from Mr. It, J. Price, the chairman ol the Nile Valloy Company, who recently visited tho mine, in which ho said he was delighted to Bay that trewsi very much pleased with what he saw-rfEe'reef had a good appearauce, and Mr, Norbury was able to show visible gold. He had a high opinion ol tho prospects of the company, and congratulated them upon their staff at the mine.

With regard to the Dongola Concession, Mr. Carey was dispatched to the concession to locate old workiugs. Tho area was very largo, but in the tint season's work be not only- located several old workings and mode a geo­logical survey of the concession, but also examined the southern part and sunk several small pita or shafts to see if he coaid discover any well-defined coal measures. Diamond drilling was now in progress to try to find a workable seam of coal If one was struck the value would be enormous, and ho believed that their chances wero more than even of doing ho. To confirm this he consulted with Mr. Mills, an eminent coal expert, wlm bad written him & letter, in which ho expressed the belief that coat would be found. (Applause.) This conces­sion wak, .! course, an immensely valuable asset to Block "E,’' and contained great pos­sibilities- Any of the old workings in the north might prove of sufficient value to form hsidiaries; and again in the south, if they ok a workable seam of coal, it would neces- e the formation of a large company. The u-Government hod authorised the capita- jn of a syndicate to more thoroughly .re and develop this concession, with -apital of £100,000, £50,000 of which i-Ji was to he working capital. A financial •tip in London was dosirioue of taking up is concession, and it wae a question with the uirectors whether it would bo better to offer at to the shaicliuldera or complete negotiations with this group. A survey had also been made of the agricultural land bordering tho Nile, in consequence of which an application was made for a-grant of *0,000 acres, The Government . had informed them by cable that they were - willing to grant 25,000 acres, and the remaining 15,000 acres was atiEI under consideration. The Sudan Govermeut were not disponed to grant agricultural land to mining companies; hut, recognising the work the company had done! they had made ihe grant on condition that it should be undertaken by a separate company, 'ihe idea was that there should be a large company, with a capital of £400,000 and a working capital of £250,000, and the directors were in negotiation with a strong group,with a view to taking this up. (Hear, boar.) In con­clusion be thought the facts he had given showed that the Block “K” a»sois must ultimately be of very great value. He mow! the adoption of the report and accounts.
The motion was at once agreed to.

p.hi: An extraordinary meeting of the company was Utea held, when the Chairman moved the four
p.note:
resolutions appearing on the notice. The first and second resolutions—increasing the increasing by the creation of 20,000 now shares of £1 each, and directing that 6,000 of such new shares be offered to the members of the company in the proportion of one now share for every five existing share-, were unanimously
Office to.
The Chairman next proposed a resolution approving ihe agreement between the company ami Mr. E. A. Jload guaranteeing the subscri|>- tion of the said 6,000 shares.
On this being pot to the meeting, about 20 voted in favor and 7 against.
Mr. H. J, Ircdale demanded a poll.
The Chairman moved the fourth resolution relating to the directors’ control of tho new share.-’, and tliia was declared carried by 2t> votes to 5.
Mr, Parker moved the fifth rosolution deal­ing with the remunoniticiii of the di roc tors, and increasing. the amount from £150 to tho chairman ami £100 to each of tho directors per annum to £300 amt £200 respectively.
Mr. Beal seconded the motion, and this was unanimously agreed to.
Subsequently Mr. lredale intimated that, in deference to the views of the majority of shareholders, he would withdrew bis demand for a poll. A vote of thanks was accorded tho chairman for his lucid speech, and the proceedings then terminated.
THE EGYPTIAN FELLAH
FOLK SONGS.
A very interesting little collection of folk songs collected at Sakkara by Professor J let "rich Schaefer during the winter of 1900-1, during tile excavations of the Berlin Museum at the. Some -IQ, says the author, were contributed by u black Ibrahim E Sudani, whose family had bean settled in Egypt for some generation*; the remainder weeo mostly contributed by a gbaffir named Mahmoud Molmmod El Etr. The songs are quite short not one exceeds 2'* lines ami porno are simply con plots, while others re­semble the south German ‘Sdiuoedor-.nnpll' or the Irish ‘Loobeen’ in which one or mare of a party sings a verse or couplet which is answered by the rest. Here is on example Question. Ya banat, yalli bctimlu Kir-el-morado kam A nstcer. Asbara min aba la’a
Wabm min takht el-huzam. which being translated goes as follow*
.You girls who are drawing water How much is the rent of tho watering [place 1
AfMPef. Ten ol those with tho window
(i o. sovereigns)
And a kiss under the nose ring.
The majority ol the songs are love songs (war and politic*, have no place in tho collec­tion) and some of them nro ol a high quality, spontaneous, artless, and fail ol deep feeling. “Khabat el iiGWa fil-hab14 is a delightful little verse, but One cannot help regretting that tho songs are so short European folk-songs on an average have more than twoor three Conplotxand there Egyptian songs conttin enough to make a reader certain that the fellab Lai not had all the poetry ground out.of him. The workmen’s songs are also interesting and there are two capital stanzas describing tho different recep­tion.-? accorded to tho wearers ol the tarboush and the 'libdV or felt cap. By tho way, we miss tho pleasing chorea ascribed to the peasant poets of the Delta ■—
El mufottish ioglesi gaih Hat el-wiski, hat os-soda !
But perhaps that has not reached Sakkara yet.
MOHAMEDAN EDUCATION. Since he went out to assume- .command ol the farce* in India Viscount Kitchener has seldom spoken in public on non-military oc- carioM, but on March 1 his Excellency pre­sented the prizes to successful students ol the Calcutta Mad roach, and briefly addressed the assembly. He said he could not help feeling that the honor of being invited to take part in tho function was duo to his having been the founder of a similar insti­tution to theirs in Khartoum. They would be glad to learn that the Gordon College there was progressing in a most satisfactory manner and was affording ednoation to a large number of their oo-religiunista It was now apparent that tho hope he expressed when his appeal for funds in England was so generously respouded to, that tho Gordon College would eventually becomo the centre of light and learning for the greater part ol Northern Africa, was no visionary ideal, but was in a fair way of being realised in the near future. Parents in all petitions and classes iu the Sudan wore most an­xious to send their sons to the collage, and ho was pleased to announce that the nu thorities of the institution had decided to add another wing to tho building, sc it* to afford the much-required increased accom modatiun foF students. English men and women gave generously to establish and maintain such institutions as theirs, not merely that geography, history, and wiener might be taught, but to enable the youths Ol Mohamedan races Under our rule to carry out that grand Mohamedan precept, which was also the precept of other religions, that to improve the mind and body was the duty of man to God. The British Government and people did all in tboir power to pay back the debt they owed the East in phi losophy, science, literature, and art by exbs- hifehteg and maintaining such institution". He trusted bi* young auditors would make the knowledge they gained at the Madrasah ft stoppings tone to future study and im­provement,

Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
